text: Thank you so much for Dr. Sharabi and for affording me this chance to speak to a very distinguished audience, so I was told. I mean, I know my friends, but I don't know the rest. But I was alerted that you will have a very sophisticated audience here. So I'm already awed by your presence. But hopefully we will be able to establish some kind of rapport where we can enter in dialogue regarding this very sensitive issue of Zionism and racism. As I said in yesterday's lecture, I'm a graduate of American universities. I got my PhD in English and American Romantic Poetry from Rutgers University in Columbia. And we learned how to think critically here. And this is very important. You know, we learned how to distinguish between the subjective and objective, between the ideal and the desirable and the possible. I mean, we came to understand that we have to have first a system of classification, a sophisticated taxonomy to be able to enter in a dialogue with the other. And this is the only way to have a rational discourse. But when I look at the American discourse regarding the Middle East, I'm really baffled. It makes no sense. I have just finished my autobiography, and that takes a large part of it. Here I am, learning about rationalism, enlightenment, humanism, what have you. And then I'm told about the promised land, about the – I mean, and this is me, an Egyptian. Imagine a Palestinian sitting there, and he's told about the promised land, the Holocaust taking place in Europe, and he has to vacate his homeland so that the victims should come and find a place. You know what King Nisaud, a Bedouin king, had to say? Very commonsensical. He told President Roosevelt, why don't you give them part of Germany? We laugh, but you see, we have been – we have lost our innocence, in a sense, so much so that something that's so commonsensical makes us laugh because we know it's impossible. But why is it impossible? Because the Bible says there are certain premises, certain cognitive maps in our minds. And therefore, we look at the Balfour Declaration, talking of 90 percent of the population of Palestine referred to as the non-Jewish communities, and that we accept as the Bedouin king when he makes a commonsensical statement. We laugh at it. You see, we have been completely corrupted by this discourse. So the way to start, really, is to deconstruct this discourse, to understand how can the American administration and the Israeli administration think that Arafat can stop the Intifada? What makes them think this way? Whereas any street boy in Palestine would know that this is impossible. Actually, I think most Israelis know that this is impossible. So let us look at some of the initial premises that would make an American spokesman espouse the apocalyptic terminology of Zionism. Yet, when he turns to the Palestinians, he grows all of a sudden pragmatic, telling them, why don't you find another place? We'll give you some economic aid. Isn't that enough for you? And when he turns to the Zionist state, he talks about ancestral homeland, things which we learned as we were studying romantic poetry. Actually, I argue in an article that Zionism is basically a romantic movement. But then, so are all fascisms. Yes, the idea of a return to an absolute, to Zion. The idea of identifying between the poet and nature. So here is the identification between the settler and the state of Israel. I mean, I enumerate. I mean, the whole organic idea that permeates Nazi discourse permeates Zionist discourse as well. There is, at the center of the discourse, there is an organic metaphor that sees certain inevitability of union between the Jew and the promised land. And that tie is so inextricable that it cannot be set together. And that the Jew, this organic Jew, cannot fulfill himself except in that promised land. And obviously, like most fascist myths, it cannot stand the test of history, the test of time and place. Now, the initial premises that underlie the American discourse, when underlie also the American cognitive map, and that underlie the Zionist cognitive map, is that the Jews are not communities. They are not minorities. They are one people. Ein Volk. As used by Herzl. See, Herzl was very much influenced by romantic German philosophy. And that this Volk is organically related there, which gives them, or gives the members of these people, absolute rights. Whoever is there is marginalized. It's seen as incidental. His presence is incidental. And accordingly, the motto of a land without a people for a people without a land, even though it is ridiculous, even though it's enchanting in its symmetry, nevertheless, it cannot stand the test of reality. For the people, for the Jews are not a people. They are human beings, citizens of their countries. Some of them live within certain disabilities. Others are enjoying, but they are not living eternally longing to go back to the state of Israel, to Zion or whatnot. And the same is true of the Palestinians. It is not a land without a people. And this cognitive map, as I point out, has been challenged through these. What the Zionists did, though, I mean, I'm always asking the question, then what is Zionism? I start off by saying that it is not a Jewish phenomenon. Its discourse is not Jewish discourse. And anyone who knows anything about Orthodox Judaism, which is the standard kind of Judaism, would know that Zionism is not a Jewish phenomenon at all. And Israel is not a Jewish state. In my history of Zionism, I point out that Zionist thought was fully formulated in the writings of Sir Earl of Shaftesbury VII and Sir Lawrence Oliphant, both of whom were non-Jewish Gentiles, to use the common term, and that they were anti-Semites as well, which sheds light on the whole Zionist scheme, that it's actually a scheme to rid Europe of its Jews. It's only towards the end of the 19th century that some members of this affected Jewish intelligentsia in East Europe, not in West Europe, began to see that Zionism could be a solution for their problem. But Zionism remained a movement of a minority. It was a movement of Jews, Eastern European Jews, basically, or West European Jews who wanted to stop the flow of immigrants from the East. And it was in that sense that we can understand Balfour. Balfour, when he was a prime minister of England, sponsored the Aliens Act to stop the Jews from entering England. And he is the same person who sponsored, who issued the declaration so that he would divert the Jews to the East. He promised land. For him, it's a set of colonial thing, because Balfour really was an anti-Semite as well. And he admitted to Cosima Wagner that he was an anti-Semite, that he hated the Jews. He found that they are a burden to Western civilization. And you can look up the introduction to Sokolov's History of Zionism, which he wrote, and he used this term, their burden, that they are organic people. That is a burden. To Western civilization. What the Zionists did, really, was to transpose transcendental religious concepts from their metaphoric transcendental level to a more literal one. So, for instance, the Jews are a people in a religious sense, in the tradition. They become people in the ethnic and racial sense. Zion is Zion of the heart. And the return is something that takes place at the end of days. The Zionists make it something that happens here and now, and you can buy a round-trip ticket if you want to Zion. And so on and so on. And they created, ultimately, some kind of a metaphysic of peoplehood. Behind all of that, there was a deep hatred.

distinguished audience, so I was told.
I mean, I know my friends, but I don't know the rest.
But I was alerted that you will have a very sophisticated audience here.
So I'm already awed by your presence.
But hopefully we will be able to establish some kind of rapport where we can enter in
dialogue regarding this very sensitive issue of Zionism and racism.
As I said in yesterday's lecture, I'm a graduate of American universities.
I got my PhD in English and American Romantic Poetry from Rutgers University in Columbia.
And we learned how to think critically here.
You know, we learned how to distinguish between the subjective and objective, between the
ideal and the desirable and the possible.

I mean, we came to understand that we have to have first a system of classification, a sophisticated taxonomy to be able to enter in a dialogue with the other. And this is the only way to have a rational discourse. But when I look at the American discourse regarding the Middle East, I'm really baffled. It makes no sense. find a place. You know what King Nisaud, a Bedouin king, had to say? Very commonsensical. He told President Roosevelt, why don't you give them part of Germany? We laugh, but you see, we have been – we have lost our innocence, in a sense, so much so that something that's so commonsensical makes us laugh because we know it's impossible. Bible says there are certain premises, certain cognitive maps in our minds. And therefore, we look at the Balfour Declaration, talking of 90 percent of the population of Palestine referred to as the non-Jewish communities, and that we accept as the Bedouin king when he makes a commonsensical statement. We laugh at it. You see, we have been completely corrupted by this discourse.

So the way to start, really, is to deconstruct this discourse, to understand how can the American administration and the Israeli administration think that Arafat can stop the Intifada? What makes them think this way? Whereas any street boy in Palestine would know that this is impossible. Actually, I think most Israelis know that this is impossible.

So let us look at some of the initial premises that would make an American spokesman espouse the apocalyptic terminology of Zionism. Yet, when he turns to the Palestinians, he grows all of a sudden pragmatic, telling them, why don't you find another place? We'll give you some economic aid. Isn't that enough for you? And when he turns to the Zionist state,

he talks about ancestral homeland, things which we learned as we were studying romantic poetry. Actually, I argue in an article that Zionism is basically a romantic movement. But then, so are all fascisms. Yes, the idea of a return to an absolute, to Zion. The idea of identifying between the poet and nature.

So here is the identification between the settler and the state of Israel. I mean, I enumerate. I mean, the whole organic idea that permeates Nazi discourse permeates Zionist discourse as well. There is, at the center of the discourse, there is an organic metaphor that sees certain inevitability of union between the Jew and the promised land. And that tie is so inextricable that it cannot be set

together. And that the Jew, this organic Jew, cannot fulfill himself except in that promised land. And obviously, like most fascist myths, it cannot stand the test of history, the test of time and place. Now, the initial premises that underlie the American discourse, when underlie also the American cognitive map, and that underlie

the Zionist cognitive map, is that the Jews are not communities. They are not minorities. They are one people. Ein Volk. As used by Herzl. See, Herzl was very much influenced by romantic German philosophy. And that this Volk is organically related there, which gives them, or gives the members of these people,

absolute rights. Whoever is there is marginalized. It's seen as incidental. His presence is incidental. And accordingly, the motto of a land without a people for a people without a land, even though it is ridiculous, even though it's enchanting in its symmetry, nevertheless, it cannot stand the test of reality.

For the people, for the Jews are not a people. They are human beings, citizens of their countries. Some of them live within certain disabilities. Others are enjoying, but they are not living eternally longing to go back to the state of Israel, to Zion or whatnot. And the same is true of the Palestinians. It is not a land without a people.

And this cognitive map, as I point out, has been challenged through these. What the Zionists did, though, I mean, I'm always asking the question, then what is Zionism? I start off by saying that it is not a Jewish phenomenon. Its discourse is not Jewish discourse. And anyone who knows anything about Orthodox Judaism, which is the standard kind of Judaism, would know that Zionism is not a Jewish phenomenon at all.
And Israel is not a Jewish state.
In my history of Zionism, I point out that Zionist thought was fully formulated in the writings of Sir Earl of Shaftesbury VII and Sir Lawrence Oliphant,
both of whom were non-Jewish Gentiles, to use the common term, and that they were anti-Semites as well,

which sheds light on the whole Zionist scheme, that it's actually a scheme to rid Europe of its Jews. It's only towards the end of the 19th century that some members of this affected Jewish intelligentsia in East Europe, not in West Europe, began to see that Zionism could be a solution for their problem. But Zionism remained a movement of a minority.

It was a movement of Jews, Eastern European Jews, basically, or West European Jews who wanted to stop the flow of immigrants from the East. And it was in that sense that we can understand Balfour. Balfour, when he was a prime minister of England, sponsored the Aliens Act to stop the Jews from entering England. And he is the same person who sponsored, who issued the declaration so that he would divert the Jews to the East.
For him, it's a set of colonial thing, because Balfour really was an anti-Semite as well.
And he admitted to Cosima Wagner that he was an anti-Semite, that he hated the Jews.
He found that they are a burden to Western civilization.
And you can look up the introduction to Sokolov's History of Zionism, which he wrote, and he
used this term, their burden, that they are organic people.

To Western civilization. What the Zionists did, really, was to transpose transcendental religious concepts from their metaphoric transcendental level to a more literal one. So, for instance, the Jews are a people in a religious sense, in the tradition. They become people in the ethnic and racial sense. Zion is Zion of the heart. And the return is something

that takes place at the end of days. The Zionists make it something that happens here and now, and you can buy a round-trip ticket if you want to Zion. And so on and so on. And they created, ultimately, some kind of a metaphysic of peoplehood. Behind all of that, there was a deep hatred.
